@ijuma I have changed the code (quite a bit). I think we don't want to add warnings in the broker when clients disconnect. So I have moved the warning to `NetworkClient`. Have also added warnings for the connection refused case that you mentioned in the JIRA. The additional state in `KafkaChannel` will also be useful if we decide to go ahead with KIP-152 to have a more definitive authentication-failed state.
Thanks @rajinisivaram, will take a look soon.

@baluchicken Thank you for the PR. There was a failure with the same symptoms with this PR (https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/3547/testReport/kafka.api/SaslGssapiSslEndToEndAuthorizationTest/testTwoConsumersWithDifferentSaslCredentials/). Unfortunately, only warning level logs are available, so the extra info level log didn't help. Can you see if you can catch the server startup exception and log the `jaasContext` that was written and then rethrow the exception? If you can't get to the `jaasContext` easily, you could just read the file based on the system property and display that (at error level in the catch block).
This is an initial PR to get some feedback on whether I'm on the right track. Need to write tests and verify if any additional work needs to be done to clean-up metrics. cc @onurkaraman @junrao

That's a new one:
```
org.apache.kafka.connect.runtime.WorkerTest > testCleanupTasksOnStop FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: 
      Expectation failure on verify:
        WorkerSourceTask.run(): expected: 1, actual: 1
        at org.easymock.internal.MocksControl.verify(MocksControl.java:225)
        at org.powermock.api.easymock.internal.invocationcontrol.EasyMockMethodInvocationControl.verify(EasyMockMethodInvocationControl.java:132)
```

Hi @dguy, I think you have a good point: 

If the transactionManager is an error state, we only block a commit from being propagated. I think we should extend this to block _any_ transactional request from being sent. I already improved this logic a bit to block only commits and not aborts  in my integration test brach [see here](https://github.com/apurvam/kafka/blob/exactly-once-integration/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/internals/TransactionManager.java), and we can extend that to block all transactional requests except aborts.

Also, once the transaction manager is in an error state, no further transactional sends will be allowed [see this](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.java#L738). In that case, the user will get the authorization failed exception from the send future. 

So with a little tweak to block all transactional requests except aborts from an error state, we should be pretty solid in handling this on the client side, no?

Regarding the case when the `ProducerIdResource` authorization fails, in `Sender.maybeWaitForPid`, it might make sense to check if the exception is fatal and put the `transactionManager` in an error state and use the existing logic in `KafkaProducer` to fail all future sends. This would be a consistent and intuitive way to handle it. 

@dguy @hachikuji what do you think?
retest this please
@ijuma yes, sure! now it's ready
